column6: Disclosure Name
column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
column7: Transurban operates in urban centres of Australia (Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane), the United States (Virginia) and Canada (Montreal). The vast majority of Transurban's supply chain spend is on suppliers and activities that are physically locally based around its roads, projects, and offices in each respective city. Some spending relates to group-wide services or technology services shared across regions.

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column13: Transurban has an Anti-Bribery, Corruption and Fraud Policy and a Conflicts Management Policy, reinforcing its governance, anti-corruption and integrity framework and supporting a culture of acting lawfully, ethically and responsibly within Transurban. These policies define the standard required from Transurban's Directors, employees, and third parties when working with Transurban, highlight the processes for prevention, detection, and investigation of reports of fraudulent or corrupt conduct, and provide guidance concerning managing and recording gifts and benefits.
column20: Anti-Bribery and Corruption Policy, governance, corrupt conduct

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: Transurban implemented a practical and proactive Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) Framework, which applies to all its business activities, operations and projects. The ERM Framework is aligned with industry better practice and is consistent with the ISO 31000:2018 risk management standard. The ERM Framework guides identifying, assessing, managing and escalating risks to ensure that key risks are escalated appropriately for decision-making and proactive management.
column20: Enterprise Risk Management Framework, ISO 31000:2018, proactive management

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: The Employee Policy Handbook is an internal document provided to employees to support the Code of Conduct concerning US operations. This policy details information on harassment, misconduct, anti-bribery and corruption, overtime policies, employee entitlements and the whistleblower hotline.
column20: Employee Policy Handbook, internal document, Code of Conduct

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
column7: Transurban has not been exposed to corruption-related incidents, so no action against employees or service providers has been required.

column6: Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices
column7: Transurban has no cases of antitrust.

column6: Approach to tax
column7: Transurban's internal corporate governance functions support its Board's role in maintaining oversight and monitoring the effectiveness of the tax governance framework.

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: Transurban's Board-approved Tax Risk Management Policy is premised on accountability and ownership of tax risk. As such, Transurban's approach is governed by Transurban's commitment to best-practice corporate governance, transparency and accountability. It is essential for the long-term performance and sustainability of the business and to protect and enhance the interests of security holders and other stakeholders.
column20: Tax Risk Management Policy, accountability, tax risk

column6: Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax
column7: Transurban maintains a cooperative relationship with other revenue authorities in Australia and overseas.

column6: Country-by-country reporting
column7: In addition to its Australian operations, Transurban has operations across the North American region comprising the 95, 395 and 495 Express Lanes in the Greater Washington area (US) and the A25 in Montreal (Canada). Some of Transurban's Australian entities engaged in international-related party dealings to support the effective operations of its North American assets.

column6: Materials used by weight or volume
column13: Transurban is developing a Sustainable Resource Strategy to improve its measurement of materials and waste and set group-wide targets. Transurban monitors materials quantities on major projects individually and develops group-wide materials quantities totals.
column20: Sustainable Resource Strategy, material quantity, waste

column6: Recycled input materials used
column13: Several initiatives were implemented on the WestConnex M4-M8 link tunnels during the construction phase, resulting in a 57% reduction in embodied emissions in materials compared with the initial base case design. These initiatives included cement substitution, 15% reclaimed asphalt pavement in its asphalt mix, and an overall reduction in the volume of steel used.
column20: Emissions, cement substitution, reclaimed asphalt pavement

column6: Reclaimed products and thei packaging materials
column7: Transurban's only physical product is tolling tags, provided to customers to enable toll road travel. Tags that customers return and still function may be reused.

column6: Energy consumption within the organization
column7: Transurban consumed 999,171 GJ of energy in 2023.

column6: Energy consumption outside of the organization
column7: Transurban reports on its supply chain outside the organisation based on Scope 3 emissions but does not convert this into an energy basis.

column6: Energy intensity
column13: In FY23, Transurban hosted a team from Monash University as part of the Monash Industry Team Initiative. The team worked on opportunities for Transurban to further support the uptake of electric vehicles (EVs) in Australia, in line with its sustainability commitments.
column20: Monash Industry Team, Monash University, electric vehicle

column6: Reduction of energy consumption
column13: Ventilation systems account for a significant portion of the energy needed to operate road tunnels. Through advanced analytics data modelling and real-time airflow simulations, Transurban can maximise the efficiency of many of its tunnel ventilation systems while maintaining air quality standards. In FY23, ventilation optimisation initiatives helped Transurban achieve energy efficiency savings in Transurban's assets, including Clem7 8%, Cross City Tunnel 17% and CityLink 8%.
column20: Ventilation system, energy efficiency, analytics data modelling

column6: Reductions in energy requirements of products and services
column7: By providing customers with safer, faster and more free-flowing travel choices on its roads, Transurban estimates that, on average, its customers save on average 28% of their fuel usage driving on a Transurban toll road compared to the next best available un-tolled alternative route.

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column7: Transurban's water use and impacts include using potable or recycled water for its operations, including offices, road cleaning and maintenance, fire control systems, and irrigation.

column6: Management of water discharge-related impacts
column13: In FY23, Transurban opened a new water treatment plant to treat the almost 340 kilolitres of water that Sydney's M5 East tunnel and motorway collects daily. Once treated and tested to meet environmental obligations, the water is released into a nearby creek system.
column20: Water treatment plant, environmental obligation, creek system

column6: Water withdrawal
column7: Transurban withdrew 1,869,832 m3 of groundwater in 2023.

column6: Water discharge
column7: Transurban recycled 141,878 m3 of water in 2023.

column6: Water consumption
column7: Transurban consumed 275,894 m3 of water in 2023.

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column7: Transurban had five motorways adjacent to areas with high biodiversity value.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Transurban intends to develop a broader company-wide biodiversity strategy. Flora and fauna management plans are maintained at the regional level, consistent with local regulations and habitat. In some areas, motorways pass through areas of fragmented natural habitat and impact wildlife movement. It also leads to the potential for animals crossing motorways. Where applicable, Transurban maintains motorway fencing and fauna crossing availability to channel animals to safe crossing locations.\t
column20: Biodiversity strategy, flora and fauna management plan, natural habitat

column6: Habitats protected or restored
column13: Transurban's ongoing habitat restoration projects included partnering with Landcare Australia on the Power St Loop in Melbourne and M2 Motorscapes in Sydney. Major projects also focus on protecting or enhancing local habitats where possible. The Logan Enhancement Project in Brisbane included a major "fauna bridge" and wildlife connectivity improvements.
column20: Habitat restoration projects, Landcare Australia, local habitat

column6: IUCN Red List species and national conversation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations
column7: Transurban's A25 bridge in Montreal spans a river inhabited by sturgeon, which are present on the IUCN Red List, with some species listed as endangered.

column6: Direct (Scope 1) GHG emissions
column7: Transurban's scope 1 emissions in 2023 were 5,839 tCO2e.
